Post_Time: 2d ‚Ä¢2 days ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
Post_Content:
üåü From Server Crashes to a Comeback: Trying to Revive WatchWithMeüåü
We‚Äôre excited to share an update on
https://watchwithme.in
, our service designed to let long-distance couples enjoy Netflix, Prime Video, and other streaming services together seamlessly. With integrated audio/video calls, chat and Sync, it‚Äôs like sharing a movie night, no matter the distance. Launched a year ago as a free service, WatchWithMe grew steadily without any much of a marketing, purely through word-of-mouth love from our users by various countries and continents.
But here‚Äôs the honest truth: we hit a rough patch. After five months of intense development, personal circumstances led us to pause maintenance for 1-2 months. This caused a critical issue with room joining and user logins, crashing our servers whenever existing users tried to log back in. Our robust infrastructure and auto-reconnecting sessions built by
Harish Kumar K
kept things from completely falling apart, but we saw a steep decline in active users over those two months.
Now, we‚Äôre fully focused on turning things around and bringing WatchWithMe back stronger than ever. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôve been working on:
- Implemented Cloud-Watch logs to pinpoint the issue.
- Patched all the immediate bugs and implemented side-panels on all areas
- Built a more user metrics dashboard to track usage trends and regional activity.
- Started rolling out advanced user and product analytics
We‚Äôre committed to reviving WatchWithMe and making it better than ever for couples worldwide. If you‚Äôre in a long-distance relationship or know someone who is, we‚Äôd love for you to try it out. Share your thoughts or favorite streaming picks in the comments!

Post_Content:
Looking at this view, I‚Äôm reminded of how vast the world really is.
Too often, we pick one thing and make our entire life about it. Passion is powerful, but the world is too big ‚Äî and one lifetime is too short ‚Äî to stay in just one stream.
Explore more. Try different paths. Have fun along the way. Because living fully is about collecting experiences, not just mastering one. üåç‚ú®

Post_Author_JobTitle: SDE II @ Pickyourtrail | Triplebyte CertifiedSDE II @ Pickyourtrail | Triplebyte Certified
Post_Time: 2w ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢2 weeks ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
Post_Content:
Sometimes the smallest bugs create the biggest storms.
Cloudflare, a company that has stopped some of the largest DDoS attacks in history, recently faced an outage because of‚Ä¶ a misplaced React useEffect dependency.
An object recreated on every render tricked React into thinking it was "new," triggering an infinite loop of API calls. The result? A self-inflicted DDoS.
There‚Äôs something poetic about a world-class DDoS shield being brought down not by hackers, but by a single line of frontend code.
A reminder for all of us: in engineering, even the tiniest details matter.

Post_Author_JobTitle: SDE II @ Pickyourtrail | Triplebyte CertifiedSDE II @ Pickyourtrail | Triplebyte Certified
Post_Time: 3w ‚Ä¢3 weeks ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
Post_Content:
Hot take: Negative reviews can be more valuable to a startup than positive ones.
While positive reviews provide a sense of satisfaction, they often lack in-depth insights. On the other hand, negative reviews offer a treasure trove of information. They pinpoint areas of weakness, highlight confusion, and identify missing elements.
Each complaint serves as invaluable product research without the cost.
By addressing negative feedback effectively, startups not only resolve issues but also strengthen trust with their audience. Embracing and learning from negative reviews is key to growth and improvement for any startup.
